name: Bupropion SR (Zyban)
summary: A sustained-release formulation of bupropion used for smoking cessation and as an antidepressant.
description: Bupropion SR (Zyban) is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI) approved for smoking cessation and also used as an antidepressant. Unlike SSRIs, it has minimal sexual side effects and may aid in energy and concentration. In smoking cessation, it reduces nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms. The sustained-release (SR) formulation allows twice-daily dosing.

contraindications: Current or prior diagnosis of bulimia or anorexia nervosa
Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol, benzodiazepines, barbiturates, or antiepileptics

sections.text: Bupropion inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, increasing their synaptic availability. It also acts as a non-competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, reducing nicotine cravings.

adult.start: 150 mg once daily for 3 days, then 150 mg twice daily
adult.titrate: Increase after initial period if tolerated

sections.geriatric: Use with caution; consider lower doses
sections.hepatic_impairment: Reduce dose/frequency in moderate to severe impairment
sections.renal_impairment: Use with caution; adjust dose if needed

sections.text: Onset for smoking cessation benefit within 1–2 weeks; full antidepressant effect may take 4–6 weeks.

sections.black_box: Antidepressants increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults.
other: Risk of seizures increases with higher doses and in predisposed individuals

sections.pregnancy: Use if benefits outweigh risks; limited human data
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; monitor infant
sections.pediatrics: Not approved for smoking cessation in children

sections.text: May discontinue without taper, but gradual reduction can minimize withdrawal-like symptoms.

items: Advise patients to set a quit date within 1–2 weeks of starting
Can be combined with nicotine replacement for some patients
SR formulation reduces dosing frequency compared to IR
